critical_finding.reason: PowerShare is a load curtailment demand response program where customers voluntarily reduce energy consumption during peak demand periods. Customers determine their own curtailment methods, which can include battery discharge, load shifting, generator use, or equipment shutdown. Battery systems can participate by discharging to reduce grid load during events.
critical_finding.recommendation: SUITABLE FOR COMMERCIAL BATTERY OPTIMIZATION - Provides capacity payments for load reduction capability. Can stack with behind-the-meter arbitrage strategies.

research_notes: CRITICAL CORRECTION: User indicated 'North Carolina is in PJM Interconnection territory' - this is INCORRECT for Duke Energy Carolinas service area. Duke Energy Carolinas and Duke Energy Progress in NC are NOT in PJM. Only Duke Energy Ohio and Duke Energy Kentucky participate in PJM. A small Dominion-served area in northeastern NC participates in PJM, but Duke's Carolinas territories do not.
PowerShare is technology-agnostic demand response program - customers choose curtailment method (battery discharge, generator, load reduction, etc.)
Battery participation is INDIRECT: batteries reduce load by discharging, not through direct utility dispatch like PowerPair residential VPP
Program received 42.9% incentive increase effective January 1, 2025 ($3.50 → $5.00 per kW)
EnergyWise Business is separate program for smaller customers with higher per-kW rate ($50) but utility-controlled equipment
Duke Energy opposes RTO/ISO membership - maintains vertically integrated monopoly structure in Carolinas
During December 2022 Winter Storm Elliott, Duke could not access PJM markets for emergency power purchases
Battery revenue opportunities severely limited compared to RTO/ISO territories - no wholesale energy, capacity, or ancillary service markets
Duke planning massive utility-owned storage expansion (5,600 MW by 2034) but limited customer-sited battery programs beyond residential pilot
Full tariff document access needed for complete operational parameters - public materials provide program overview only
SEEM (Southeast Energy Exchange Market) provides bilateral trading but not organized market with DER participation rules like RTO/ISO
